awd_titl_txt: Novel Processes and Materials in Bioengineering and Biomedical Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal: 0754590
PI Name: Linninger, Andreas

The three year REU site award will provide a unique summer research experience focused in the area of bioengineering and biomedicine for mixed teams of undergraduate students who will be collaborating with math and science teachers and gifted high school students. This REU site program will be integrated with the Chicago Science and Math Teacher Research (CSTR) program, an already existing NSF Research Experiences for Teachers Program (RET) and an existing high school student mentoring program with the Illinois Math and Science Academy. The aims of this REU site are to: (1) introduce students to state-of-the-art multidisciplinary research content and practice; (2) enhance students' creativity and prepare them for graduate studies; (3) promote the development of professional skills needed in the engineering workplace; and (4) strengthen students' self-confidence by improved leadership and communication skills. Specific research projects offered in this REU site will include drug transport and biomolecular technology, biomechanics, nanotechnology, microfabrication and molecular biology, bioinformatics for molecular drug design and characterization.  This site is also unique because it will bring together bioengineers with faculty in neuroscience, oncology, medicinal chemistry and orthopedics.  

In order to enhance the hands-on laboratory research experience, a variety of additional activities have been incorporated. These include the following: (1) an ethics component: (2) lectures on communication and leadership skills; (3) a workshop on laboratory safety; (4) industrial site visits; (5) tours to clinical and research facilities at the University of Illinois Medical Campus, the University of Chicago Hospitals and Rush University Medical Center; (6) group visits to sporting events, architectural boat tours on Lake Michigan and other recreational facilities in the Chicago area; (7) weekly social lunch time get-togethers; and (8) a PI hosted summer reception for REU and RET fellows, mentors and graduate students. 

Eighty percent of the REU participants will be recruited from underrepresented groups.  Results of the research will be disseminated in scientific publications. All REU participants will be required to prepare a technical paper and all presentations, progress reports and technical papers will be placed on the REU/RET website.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This project comprised of an NSF REU (National Science Foundation- Research Experience for Undergraduates) site on Nanoscale Drug Targeting and Delivery in Biomedical Engineering, Life Sciences and Medicine at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC). A unique summer research experience was offered to undergraduate students from various universities in the country to work at UIC’s inter-disciplinary labs in the fields of bioengineering, life sciences and medicine. The students worked in collaboration with high school teachers and gifted high school students from the Illinois Math and Science Academy while enjoying the benefit of being advised by several mentors.  The significant results achieved during this program were:

  • Nanotechnology research was conducted at the interface of engineering, life sciences and medicine,
  • Student’s interest was stimulated for pursuing graduate studies by training them in state of the art interdisciplinary laboratories, and
  • Leadership and communication skills of the student were improved for benefit in tomorrow’s biotechnology workplace.

During this summer program, three main student activity elements were incorporated into the program-

1. Technical program with laboratory research advised by three mentors: During the ten weeks of lab research experience in established research labs at UIC and Rush University Medical Center, REU students conducted cutting edge research in state-of-the-art research facilities. The program greatly encouraged the development of decision-making, leadership, and research planning skills. 

Field of Study

List of Projects

Biomedical engineering/

Neuroscience

Shunt Obstruction Monitoring for Hydrocephalus

Glutathione based hydrogels

Development of biosensor for detection of cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers in hydrocephalus diagnosis

Magnetic Resonance Elastography

Patient specific brain vasculature model verification using the statistical values of physiological standards

Computer-aided design to engineer siRNA therapies to the central nervous system through intrathecal delivery

Advanced reconstruction of the patient-specific cerebral vasculature

Bench-top calibration and animal testing of intracranial volume sensor

Autoregulation of Cerebral Blood Flow

Animal Validation of a Volume Based Sensor to Monitor Hydrocephalus

Computer Assisted Modeling of Convection Enhanced Drug Delivery to the Brain

Computational Modeling of Cerebral Vasculature

Gene Therapy for the Treatment of Gliomas

Neural Basis of Motivation Studied with Intracranial Injection

Multi-Channel Data Acquisition and Processing

System for the Human Subject Experiments of The Audible Human Project 

Self-Assembly of Dendritic Copolymers

Nucleus Accumbens and Motivated Salt Feeding in Rat

Quantification of Animal Experiments Using Rigorous Pharmacokinetic Models

Bioengineering

/Neuroscience

 

Electric field-guided carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) for targeting high-grade brain tumors

Osteogenic differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cell (hMSC) with 2D and 3D superporous hydrogel culture...
